awd_titl_txt: High Resolution Solar Physics: Past, Present, Future
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar physics is a branch of physics/astronomy focused on the study of the Sun.  Magnetic fields are especially important to the physics of the Sun since they can drive phenomena such as the solar wind, solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  These phenomena, collectively referred to as space weather, directly influence the Earth and our technologically dependent society.  The goal of this project is to conduct a stand-alone workshop that will bring together scientists that use high-resolution telescopes and instrumentation to study magnetic fields in the various layers of the solar atmosphere.  These types of in-person meetings are essential to advancing the field of solar physics and provide important training opportunities for the next generation of scientists.  

The workshop on high-resolution solar physics will be held August 6-11, 2017 at the Sacramento Peak Observatory in Sunspot, New Mexico.  The workshop entitled High Resolution Solar Physics: Past, Present, Future will bring together researchers from the solar community to discuss the current state of the art in high-resolution, ground-based observations of the Sun from the photosphere to the corona.  Topics will include:  the photosphere at high resolution, the chromosphere at high resolution, high-resolution flare observations, new high-resolution coronal techniques, and observational plans for the NSF's new Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope.

por.por_cntn:
On August 07-11, 2017, members of the international scientific community gathered at Sacramento Peak (Sunspot, New Mexico) to address the topic ?High-resolution Solar Physics: Past, Present, Future,? including high-resolution observing from space and with ALMA and high resolution in numerical modeling. The primary goal of the workshop was to point the way towards the required observations and theory needed to fully understand the solar magneto-plasma interactions. Modeling has indicated that much if not most of the important physics lies below current observational limits. The workshop participants discussed the observations needed with the new higher resolution facilities currently under development, in particular, the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST) and the accompanying modeling efforts. More than 80 participants (41 US and 44 foreign participants representing 13 countries) actively contributed to a successful workshop; 22 of the participants were graduate students (8), postdoctoral fellows (5), and early-career scientists (9).

The workshop included reviews of the outstanding science performed during the past half century at the Sacramento Peak Observatory, which has played a major role in the development of our current picture of the solar atmosphere, including photosphere, chromosphere and corona. Sac Peak has also played a strong role in the development of instrumentation needed to unravel magnetic field-plasma interactions.

Examples include universal and narrowband tunable filters, the use of high-speed visible and IR digital cameras, spectropolarimeters, and the development of solar adaptive optics which makes possible the next generation of large aperture solar telescopes.

The Workshop covered the following topics from both a historical and future oriented perspective. Current and future observations, instruments, and modeling/simulations were discussed for each topic.

(a) photosphere at high resolution; (b) chromosphere at high resolution; (c) high resolution flare observations; (d) new high-resolution coronal techniques; (e) DKIST observational plans.

Workshop participants reviewed current photospheric observations and discussed outstanding issues in photospheric research, including high-resolution observing principles and techniques as well as new, non-traditional ways of obtaining two-dimensional images at high temporal resolution; the latter is extremely important because, on the small scales needed to understand field-plasma interactions, the atmosphere is evolving rapidly.

Magnetic fields observed in the chromosphere and higher are rooted in the photosphere. Unfortunately, current observational understanding of these layers is even more rudimentary than those of the photosphere. The motions imparted to the field in the photosphere can drive a variety of propagating waves that carry energy into these higher atmospheric layers. The deposition of this energy heats the chromosphere and corona in ways still not understood and can destabilize existing field structures in these layers leading to activity. We?re in the early stages of learning how to observe chromospheric fields and waves and relating them to photospheric observations. One of the workshop sessions was devoted to chromospheric observations at high resolution, including state-of-the-art in chromospheric polarimetry, filter observations, flare observations at high resolution, modeling and new techniques which leads us one step further toward understanding the chromosphere and its role in the transition from plasma-dominated photosphere to the field-dominated corona.

The goal of DKIST is to elucidate the nature of the solar magnetic field at all heights in the solar atmosphere. Workshop participants provided significant input toward defining the current state-of-the-art in high-resolution observations and identifying the observations needed to understand solar magnetism.
